Title: Intrinsic connections and architectonics of posterior parietal cortex in the rhesus monkey
Abstract: "By means of autoradiographic and ablation-degeneration techniques, the intrinsic cortical connections of the posterior parietal cortex in the rhesus monkey were traced and correlated with a reappraisal of cerebral architectonics. Two major rostral-to-caudal connectional sequences exist. One begins in the dorsal postcentral gyrus (area 2) and proceeds, through architectonic divisions of the superior parietal lobule (areas PE and Pec), to a cortical region on the medial surface of the parietal lobe (area PGm). This area has architectonic features similar to those of the caudal inferior parietal lobule (area PG). The second sequence begins in the ventral post/central gyrus (area 2) and passes through the rostral inferior parietal lobule (areas PG and PFG) to reach the caudal inferior parietal lobule (area PG). Both the superior parietal lobule and the rostral inferior parietal lobule also send projections to various other zones located in the parietal opercular region, the intraparietal sulcus, and the caudalmost portion of the cingulate sulcus. Areas PGm and PG, on the other hand, project to each other, to the cingulate region, to the caudalmost portion of the superior temporal gyrus, and to the upper bank of the superior temporal sulcus. Finally, a reciprocal sequence of connections, directed from caudal to rostral, links together many of the above-mentioned parietal zones. With regard to the laminar pattern of termination, the rostral-to-caudal connections are primarily distributed in the form of cortical "columns" while the caudal-to-rostral connections are found mainly over the first cortical cell layer."

@InterMapRelations.Corrected_Why:
In PS82 it clearly states: "This zone correponds to area PE of Bonin and
Bailey (’47), area 5 of Brodmann (‘09), and area 5a of Vogt and Vogt (‘19)."

In PS82 it clearly states: "This zone (PE) correponds to area PE of Bonin and
Bailey (’47), area 5 of Brodmann (‘09), and area 5a of Vogt and Vogt (‘19)."
Given the discrepancies betweem those areas, this statement is too imprecise to
draw any conclusion from.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: p. 198: "It occupies the same position as Vogt and Vogt's (1919) area 7b."
p. 198: "In the parcellation of Jones & Burton (1976) this architectonic area is referred to as SII."
p. 198: "This area corresponds to the prokoniocortex (area proS) of Pandya & Sanides (1973)..."

p. 198: "Area PF, the most rostral sector of the inferior parietal lobule...corresponds to area PF of Bonin & Bailey (1947)...Caudal to area PF lies area PFG. This zone...represents a transition between areas PF and PG...The bulk of the mid and caudal inferior parietal lobule...is occupied by area PG...As described in this parcellation, PG-type cortex corresponds to area PG of Bonin & Bailey..."

p. 198: "Area PF, the most rostral sector of the inferior parietal lobule...corresponds to area PF of Bonin & Bailey (1947)...Caudal to area PF lies area PFG. @Injections.Citation: "Case 14 had an injection...in the ventral portion of the midinferior parietal lobule (area PG). There wa also some spread of isotope into the adjacent upper bank of the lateral sulcus (area PGop)..."
"...injections into the caudalmost portion of the inferior parietal lobule (areas PG and Opt)."
@Injections.Comments: The text does not mention which of the two areas is affected more heavily. A comparison of Figs. 1 and 8 seems to warrant the conclusion that most of the isotope has spread to area PG.

@Injections.Citation: "Case 18...with a small injection slightly rostral to those of cases 16 and 17..."
"...case 4...had a small isotope injection in the upper bank of the intraparietal sulcus (also area PEa)..."
"Case 5 had an injection of isotope in the caudalmost portion of the superior parietal lobule (area PEc)..."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "...terminal labeling was observed in other parts of the superior parietal lobule (areas PE and PEc), over the upper bank of the intraparietal sulcus (area PEa), and on the medial surface of the parietal lobe (areas PEc, PEci, and PGm)...did not show evidence of a projection to the parietal operculum...a small focus of label was seen in the midinferior parietal lobule (area PG)."

@Injections.Citation: "...injections on the medial surface of the hemisphere involving areas PEc and PGm..."
@Injections.Comments: The text does not mention which of the two areas is affected more heavily. A comparison of Figs. 1 and 5 seems to warrant the conclusion that most of the isotope has spread to area PGm.

publication.title: Intrinsic connections and architectonics of posterior parietal cortex in the rhesus monkey
publication.abstract: "By means of autoradiographic and ablation-degeneration techniques, the intrinsic cortical connections of the posterior parietal cortex in the rhesus monkey were traced and correlated with a reappraisal of cerebral architectonics. Two major rostral-to-caudal connectional sequences exist. One begins in the dorsal postcentral gyrus (area 2) and proceeds, through architectonic divisions of the superior parietal lobule (areas PE and Pec), to a cortical region on the medial surface of the parietal lobe (area PGm). This area has architectonic features similar to those of the caudal inferior parietal lobule (area PG). The second sequence begins in the ventral post/central gyrus (area 2) and passes through the rostral inferior parietal lobule (areas PG and PFG) to reach the caudal inferior parietal lobule (area PG). Both the superior parietal lobule and the rostral inferior parietal lobule also send projections to various other zones located in the parietal opercular region, the intraparietal sulcus, and the caudalmost portion of the cingulate sulcus. Areas PGm and PG, on the other hand, project to each other, to the cingulate region, to the caudalmost portion of the superior temporal gyrus, and to the upper bank of the superior temporal sulcus. Finally, a reciprocal sequence of connections, directed from caudal to rostral, links together many of the above-mentioned parietal zones. With regard to the laminar pattern of termination, the rostral-to-caudal connections are primarily distributed in the form of cortical "columns" while the caudal-to-rostral connections are found mainly over the first cortical cell layer."
